headline: Earth keeps breaking global heat records
context: In this week's Extreme Climate Update, we examine how hot Earth could actually get
As a heat wave baked southern Europe in July, temperatures soared to 41° Celsius (nearly 106° Fahrenheit) in Hyères, a city on the French Mediterranean coast, on July 26.

annotations.paragraph: Earth now is hotter than it’s been at any time in recorded history.
annotations.reason: This statement provides a direct and relevant fact about the current state of Earth's temperature.

annotations.paragraph: Average global temperatures shattered records on two consecutive days last week, reaching 17.09° Celsius on July 21 and then inching up still more the next day, to 17.15° C, or nearly 63° Fahrenheit. That’s almost an entire degree Celsius hotter than the planet’s average temperature of 16.25° C for every July 22 from 1990 to 2020.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific data on recent temperature records, contributing directly to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: Those new heat records come amid 13 months in a row of record-breaking temperatures on Earth — not just over land, but in the oceans too (SN: 4/29/24). Before 2023, the record highest temperature was 16.8 °C, set in August 2016. Since mid-2023, the planet has broken that 2016 threshold 58 times.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers context and historical comparison, enhancing understanding of the current heat records.

annotations.paragraph: It makes you wonder: Just how hot could Earth get? Is there a theoretical highest global average temperature? Well, we wondered that.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a speculative question without providing new information or context.

annotations.paragraph: And so Science News has launched a project to regularly note Earth’s climate extremes — and answer your questions about how to navigate our changing planet.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a project by Science News, which is not directly related to the headline about Earth's heat records.
This paragraph introduces the topic of extreme heat, which is directly related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Theoretically, it could get a lot hotter. Right after Earth formed nearly 4.6 billion years ago, the planet was still molten rock, with surface temperatures perhaps 1900° C.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides historical context on Earth's temperatures, which is relevant to understanding current heat records.

annotations.paragraph: Earth’s temperature during the Neoproterozoic Era, between about 800 million and 600 million years ago, careened between frigid and boiling, with the average planetary temperature perhaps reaching as high as 32° C. There have been similar just as hot or nearly as hot episodes in Earth’s history: 250 million years ago, when Earth had one massive continent called Pangaea; about 92 million years ago, during the Cretaceous Hothouse; around 55 million years ago, during the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum (SN: 1/11/17; SN: 10/4/06; SN: 5/7/15).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides historical context on Earth's temperature fluctuations, relevant to the discussion of current heat records.

annotations.paragraph: All of those times were largely ice-free on Earth, with high sea levels and forested polar regions. Not exactly ideal for humans.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on the conditions during past hot periods, relevant to understanding the implications of current heat records.
